title: Chelsea ace Diego Costa may be volatile but we won’t let bust-up derail title challenge, says Blues boss Antonio Conte
text:
Comments ANTONIO CONTE has warned the Diego Costa saga must not derail Chelsea’s title charge. 
Costa is back in the Blues squad against Hull — despite having his head turned by a mega-money offer from China. Reuters 6 Antonio Conte is hopeful Chelsea’s successful season will not be ruined by spat with Costa 
Conte axed his wayward striker for last weekend’s win against Leicester following a training ground bust up . Keep up to date with ALL the Chelsea news, gossip, transfers and goals on our club page plus fixtures, results and live match commentary 
And the Blues boss said: “If you want to win things, it’s vital to build unity. 
“You must make calls with players. Who starts, who goes on the bench, who is in the stands . . . 
“But I’m pleased to see this spirit in my team. We are now top of the table and that’s the most important thing.” 
Thibaut Courtois also backed Costa’s return — and claimed his team-mate was injured against the Foxes and NOT punished for a bust-up with coach Julio Tous. 
The Belgian keeper said: “This week he could train again and Costa trained very well. He looks very committed. PA:Press Association Costa may return to Conte’s starting line up against Hull 
“We cannot doubt that about Diego — you see it in all games he plays. 
“Nobody in this team ever doubted it. So the day before the Leicester game, when that stuff all came out, it was a surprise. 
“But it didn’t affect us as we know the truth. The rest try to destabilise Chelsea — but we won’t let it. 
“We saw him every day and know he was injured. After two days off he trained, first with the physio, then us. Everything is OK.” 
Costa is no stranger to training ground bust-ups — and clashed over money in Spain. 
But his row during a loan spell at Albacete eight years ago was over non-playing staff getting their wages on time. Other clashes were with team-mates and coaches in Spain before he headed to the Premier League with Chelsea. 
He was axed from Antonio Conte’s line-up last weekend after a dispute over his fitness AND getting his head turned by an offer from a Chinese club. 
His career has been littered with training-ground spats, as revealed in the biography ‘Diego Costa: The Art of War’ by Fran Guillen. 
Albacete’s medical assistant, Manolo Bleda, said: “The club decided to pay the players their wages, but not the rest of the staff. 
“When he heard that, Diego refused to train until everyone was paid. In 35 years I have never known anyone else take a stand like that.” Sunday Premier League match preview featuring Chelsea v Hull PA:Press Association 6 Conte is hopeful his rift with Costa will not derail their title challenge 
Guillen’s detailed account of Costa’s background also says he refused to shake the Albacete president’s hand until the kit man had been paid. 
He is painted as the dressing-room prankster, with former team-mate Verza revealing he was affectionately known as “that f***ing Brazilian”. 
But he was never far from controversy and was axed from the Albacete line-up for clashing with his keeper in training. 
Albacete coach Juan Ignacio Martínez said: “There had been a huge bust-up between him and Jonathan, our goalkeeper. I remember it was over something really trivial — one of them had asked for the ball and the other didn’t get it to him fast enough. We were playing Real Sociedad at home next and since I felt I had to be fair about it, I made both of them substitutes. 
“It was absolutely freezing and he was sitting there wrapped up in his big jacket, looking miserable. 
“I turned to my assistant, Javi Pereira, and told him to put Diego on at half-time. He just sprinted onto the pitch and in the 93rd minute scored the winning goal.” Antonio Conte talks about Diego Costa's injury and possible move to China Santiago Ferrero / MARCA 6 Diego Costa has a history of rows throughout his career including his time at Albacete 
According to Guillen’s book, Costa and Jonathan made up the following day. But he was always treading a fine line between reaching his potential and creating a storm, as team-mates described him returning for pre-season needing to shed weight. 
Ex-Atletico Madrid midfielder Juan Valera said: “He was one of the players who was always about to be transferred elsewhere, someone who was about to leave the club. 
“But you could see how fit he was, a force to be reckoned with.” 
Eventually he sealed his move to Stamford Bridge but the offers have continued to come in, with Tianjin Quanjian ready to pay him £30million a year. 
One pal of Costa’s told SunSport: “Even if he went for one season, he has enough to provide for an entire town in Brazil or generations of his family.” Diego Costa says happy New Year to his Chinese fans in vintage video Santiago Ferrero / MARCA 6 The Spain international's career is littered with controversial incidents 
The offer from the Far East turned Costa’s head last week when he missed the 3-0 win over Leicester . 
But Chelsea boss Conte will welcome him back into the squad for the home match against Hull today and insists there is plenty to come from his team with the striker leading his attack. 
Conte said: “Every team can have a lot of space, a lot of room to improve. You can improve a lot with time if you continue to work. You can try and put new knowledge in the system for your players. 
“But the most important thing is I have players who want to work. If you want them to work, but the players don’t want to, it’s very difficult. It’s important for them to see that one type of work brings us to play in this way. It’s important, I repeat, to continue to work together and also to improve our work. 
“But I’m pleased for this reason that we’ve reached this level only after five or six months. I can improve our level with more work.” Getty Images 6 Diego Costa was all smiles in Chelsea training following the bust up 
The Italian insists he is happy he has the backing of owner Roman Abramovich with whatever decisions he makes over his team selection. 
He added: “Not only for me, but for every coach. It’s important to have a strong relationship with the club, with the owner, but I think they can see my work every single day on the pitch. 
“For me, this is the most important thing. I think that every moment of my day, every single moment on the pitch in training, it is important for the club and the owner to see my work. 
“And, also, if the work is good to support me in my decisions. In every decision I take, there is always the club first, never myself.”
